reviewText: I found this to be mostly fun but disconcerting in parts. I really don't care what Fleming did in bed with his women, but the screenplay wants to tar him with a fetish for S&M. This might go a long way towards explaining his objectification of the "weaker" SEX, except that the woman he most brutalizes is also the one he feels most tenderly toward! Dominic Cooper is perfect in the role of Fleming, if not quite Bond, and the actress playing his mother made her character sufficiently loathesome. The action scenes in Germany had a kind of comic book feel to them, and that might have been fine if the adventurer in question were Bond, but it was a bit jarring in the case of the historical Fleming. I liked Fleming best when he was exchanging suggestive remarks with Miss Moneypenny, er, Monday. Recommended, but take it with a grain of salt.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Fleming" takes you into the fictionalized world of Ian Fleming, the author of the original James Bond novels. Fleming has his flaws and quite a few of them: a taste for the good life, a bit of an inferiority complex, and a lust for sensual women to name a few. Yet, he finds his calling at the outset of World War II when Britain needs imaginative people to figure out ways to thwart the Germans. This first episode quickly established Fleming's pedigree as well as his foibles. It then gets on to the business of his new job, albeit a little hastily. All the while, groundwork is laid for the future, namely Fleming's attraction to a few women who may or may not be dangerous. Superb acting, very high production value, and a well-written script take you into the world in grand style. There are a few moments of melodrama and they only do wonders for an already great production. Enjoy it more than once!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ian Fleming's James Bond books were based in part on Ian's escapades during WWII.  This was a thoroughly entertaining mini-series, set during WWII...believable and well acted.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I anxiously awaited the premiere of the show after watching the documentary on the Bond franchise. The first three episodes were highly engaging and exciting, but I felt the steam leaving the story. Instead of delving deep into Fleming’s character, the show took an all too familiar path of sexual appetites. Seriously? Once his character of playboy was established, was it necessary for episodes three and four to center around his escapades? For me, it wasn’t. I was looking for more substance with the espionage side. Is that asking too much?When I realized the last segment was going to attempt to cover the war from 1942 to 45, I choose not to watch it. And oddly, BBC America, which constantly keeps rerunning their shows, has yet to even touch the series. That tells me, the viewing audience didn’t pan out for them.Dominic Cooper was an excellent choice for Bond. He was engaging, exciting and mysterious. It was reminiscent of Sir Alex Guinness portraying Adolph Hitler in “The Ten Days of Hitler.” Superb performance.My advice, if you want to see Ian’s formative years, the first three are well worth the view. After that, might be better to enjoy a cup of tea and cakes. They’ll be more satisfying.

reviewText: Being of an appropriate age, I was personally surprised to find out what a bad-boy-war-hero, Ian was, as portrayed. The pomposity he displays is mostly enjoyable and quite, quite watchable. Ian's women, as they are performed, are both lovely to look upon, which is entirely the actresses themselves and having just the right amount of depth of character, so as to not deflect attention away from the main character, the erzatz Mr. Bond.
summary: My rating has a precedent in truth.

reviewText: Feels abbreviated. Like it should have been 12 episodes instead of four. But it is still pretty good. Costumes, setting, all vintage BBC. Nobody does it better. ;) Fleming's girlfriend is beautiful on screen. Can't argue with that shade of red lipstick. Fleming is played by Dominic Cooper and he is easy to watch. Wish we could have seen more of the brother character. The mom is wonderfully vicious. An easy 3 hours.
summary: Better than anything on network tv.

reviewText: Ian Fleming led a dissolute but active life. We've only seen the first episode, and I was surprised that It was "R" rated material at times, but the plot and actors kept us interested in the outcome. We'll watch the remaining episodes and hope that he comes to respect himself. So far, he seems to be helping the war effort.

reviewText: A slick and stylish production focusing on author Ian Fleming's wartime service and bedroom adventures. Though baby faced Dominic Cooper looks nothing like Fleming, he does manage to project that devil may care attitude that good breeding, superb connections and endless second chances might confer upon an individual.The wartime segments are less exciting than the bedroom exploits, primarily those with naughty Lady O'Neill, who is bad and beautiful. She actually manages to love the misogynistic Fleming, despite that fact she is both married [to the never seen O'Neill ] and engaging in an open affair with press baron Lord Rothermere. Lara Pulver as O'Neill, is quite wonderful, complex and mysterious-a classic femme fatale.Though Fleming dominates her in the bedroom, he can barely stand up to his formidable and well connected mummy, a brilliant and brittle Leslie Manning. Anna Chancellor as Officer Monday, the sort of no nonsense professional woman Fleming can respect, rounds up the cast at the ministry where the former wastrel actually manages to shine.Not too deep but lots of fun--and the sets, make-up and costuming are terrific.
Title: N/A

reviewText: How the producers/directors of this miniseries could make a person as interesting as Ian Fleming seem sort of dull is beyond me. Far too much attention is given to his love affair to an unsympathetic married woman (who would later become Mrs Fleming) and their S&M sex scenes (clearly meant to 'shock' and 'thrill') were so numerous that they got to be a bit 'routine' ("Here's Ian, arguing with M15, here's Ian, drinking a martini, and - oh yeah, here it comes - here's Ian whipping his girlfriend again").  It's not 'bad', but Dominic Cooper just didn't (in my opinion) have the suavity and charisma that the real Ian Fleming must surely have been in possession of.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been a Bond fan so long I can hardly remember a time when I wasn't. Accordingly, I am guarded about how the books and their author are presented. Is it credible? Is it necessary? Is it a useful addition to Bond lore? I'm happy to say FLEMING - THE MAN WHO WOULD BE BOND answers all those questions affirmatively. Only Fleming could have written Bond and only this mini-series, in my opinion, has written Fleming the way he should be, was, wanted to be, and can only be remembered. In addition to the deft treatment of Fleming himself, his environment was immaculately rendered. As a cultural historian I cringe when I hear anachronistic speech or see period incorrect clothing. FLEMING's dialogue, sets, costumes, props, and even music transport the viewer to a wartime England so perfectly constructed that one can easily lose oneself in it. Beautifully done!
summary: The story behind the man behind the story

reviewText: I know people smoked a lot back in the day (I grew up in the 50s) but this turned out to be bizarrely focused on peoples' cigarettes. It seemed as if someone said, "Act like you think people back then acted because we have a really interesting concept and a very boring screen play and not enough to fill four episodes though we should, I dunno' let's just have people smoke more. How about some gratuitous sex? Yeah? And a completely non-plot driven or driving soft core s&m extra marital love affair? Could've been really good. Was really mediocre.

reviewText: Looking over a brief biography of Ian Fleming, it's a wonder his life wasn't adapted into a television drama long ago. A failed stockbroker, a naval intelligence officer during the Second World War, a love affair with a married woman, a bestselling author - it's a life-story that's ripe for dramatization.Divided into four forty-five minute episodes "Fleming" stretches from the cusp of WWII to 1956, when he completes his first novelCasino Royalewhilst on honeymoon in Jamaica. That said, it's important to note that this miniseries isn't about the thought-process that goes into the creation of James Bond (the heavily-promoted scene that has Ian and his brother discuss potential names for his hypothetical spy is actually one of the show's final scenes), but rather explores a period of Ian Fleming's life that may have inspired the famous books.Ian is an abysmal stockbroker and part-time playboy who feels constantly in his brother's shadow, referring to himself as "the other Fleming" on introductions. A man who enjoys drinking, smoking, gambling and women, he's also the type who smiles at the announcement that war has broken out, seeing it his chance to finally prove himself. Each episode explores his exploits in the war effort (mostly espionage and the accumulation of information) as well as his torrid love affair with Anne O'Neill, a woman not only married to an army officer, but already engaged in an open affair with another man.Obviously, this isn't a wholly accurate portrayal of Ian Fleming's life, and even a quick glimpse over his Wikipedia article demonstrates that plenty of things have been changed for dramatic effect. But it beautifully captures the atmosphere of the period (the clothing, the technology, the slang) and contains plenty of fun in-jokes regarding the people and places that eventually inspire him to create James Bond. A particular treat is his rapport with female Second Officer Monday, a droll but sympathetic woman who is clearly the prototype for Moneypenny, and possibly the only woman in the entire series that Fleming actually respects.And in many ways, the miniseries attempts to portray Fleming himself as the original Bond, embroiled in espionage and surrounded by beautiful women. Embodying the arrogant nonchalance that's only attractive to women in fiction (specifically Bond films) Dominic Cooper is a good fit for the lead role, portraying Fleming as a generally decent man with significant feet of clay and a flair for storytelling. Annabelle Wallis and Lara Pulver are his inevitable "bond girls" - one a sweet and innocent blonde, the other a dark and tempestuous brunette, with Anna Chancellor as the aforementioned Second Officer Monday (I guarantee she'll end up your favourite).It's worth mentioning that the "romance" between Fleming and Ann is anything but, and a lot of viewers may be put-off by the amount of physical aggression and emotional pain that typifies their relationship. The sex scenes aren't what I'd call explicit, but the show makes it clear that there's definitely bondage and violence involved (Ann is often depicted with bruises during post-coital scenes). This is naturally meant to be a reflection of Bond's forceful pursuit of women in the novels, but consider yourself warned if you're disturbed by this sort of thing. Fleming and Ann may end the miniseries together, but it's clear that their attraction is based on the utter havoc they wreck in each other's lives.It's a bit of a shame that the creation James Bond comes so late in the miniseries, for Fleming's desperate need to be impressive (as depicted throughout all four episodes) could have made for some interesting psychological parallels in his depiction of the ever-suave, ever-extravagant Bond (was Fleming perhaps compensating for something...?) As it happens, the series *does* wink at the audience a couple of times when it comes to Fleming's propensity for storytelling, particularly when his on-screen depiction of a dangerous mission behind enemy lines is later hinted to be an entire fabrication.And as it happens, I'm a little disappointed that they never snuck in the fact that Fleming was also (eventually) the author ofChitty Chitty Bang Bang. Now THAT would have added a surprising new dimension to his character.
summary: "War is Not Some Entertainment Laid on for Your Amusement..."
Title: N/A
